By David Ramoy ‚Ä¢ Special to The Cardinal

My wife wanted to move home to Pennsylvania to be close to family, but my feet were firmly planted on the warm Florida sand, and I wasn‚Äôt budging. This all changed one year ago on a crisp fall day. We were in PA for a visit and somehow ended up in Doylestown. We had on our warm sweaters and delicious lattes from Native in hand as our two year-old son wanted to go into every store, especially Busy Bees!

I saw the leaves on the ground, the happy families at Burpee Park and delicious coffee shops as far as the eye can see. I called it the Hallmark town and was almost expecting folks to break out in song, it looked so sweet.

After a full day of walking around downtown, and admiring the many museums and the library, we headed over to Chambers 19 to grab a bite to eat. We got a table by the window to look at the leaves and elegance of the town. I ordered a pint of Guinness, and we had some french onion soup to warm ourselves up. Calling it delicious wouldn‚Äôt do it justice . . . I was in heaven.

Miraculously our son was in good spirts and not causing a ruckus.

This day changed everything. I can‚Äôt quite put my finger on it, but Doylestown has a certain ‚Äúje ne sais quoi‚Äù that‚Äôs undeniable. It only took one fall day in Downtown Doylestown for my wife to convince me to leave our lives in Florida and move here. We sat at Chambers and chatted about the town and how different it would be from our Florida lifestyle. Yes, we were giving up palm trees and winter would be coming; we just didn‚Äôt care. Doylestown in fall had enticed us.

They say fall represents change, and it definitely did for us. Fast forward to today, we sold our house in Florida, and we are here living in this delightful hallmark of a town. We‚Äôre unpacking our fall sweaters and stocking up on pumpkin spiced coffee. We couldn‚Äôt be happier.
